column10: Since I am the AP point person, my main issue has to do with the reporting on when certain bills were paid. It's hard to get an accurate Excel report on when an invoice was paid because if a credit is applied at a later date, it seems like the invoice was paid the date the credit was applied. Once I figured out how to use the remittance pdfs, that helped a little bit. Review collected by and hosted on G2.com.
column11:
I was part of a company-wide transition in ownership and financial systems. We faced many challenges in the beginning, but they have smoothed out, especially with the help of consultants and solution-oriented staff members.
Vendor maintenance has been a big part of my work. I like that Sage has a detailed audit trail and a comment section that allows you to make notes for different vendors. Sometimes searching for vendors (especially if they have a DBA name) can be an issue, but I recently learned about search shortcuts like entering % xyz% to more quickly find a vendor. Integration between Coupa (our procurement system) and Sage is an ongoing project as well. Overall, I like that Sage is very "solid" in its structure so that data isn't as easily modified. It helps to maintain transparency and reduce the number of hands in the pot. Review collected by and hosted on G2.com.

column9: I like that the system is user friendly. It's easy to navigate without much training. I like the usage functionality within the contracts module. It saves me quite a bit of time. column10: I don't like the length of time it takes to fix errors within the system. It can take months to fix revenue issues that impact closing and requires us to open books back months which creates a major risk factor. I do not like the fact that Intacct has issues regarding multi-currency, multi-entity companies. There are many issues regarding allocating funds across multi-currency, especially when trying to allocate bills. Review collected by and hosted on G2.com.
column11: We are trying to get Intacct to solve the issue regarding Multiple Element Arrangements and how the revenue is moved between the six buckets. Currently the system does not move the amounts as they should be. It only moves revenue from the lines that have an amount to bill. Once those are exhausted then it starts moving revenue from the lines without and amount to bill which is not correct. Having to determine what the true amount of deferred revenue is is very time consuming and frustrating. Review collected by and hosted on G2.com.

column9: Sage Intacct has the help bar and is easily answered/researched within the software. We can delete, edit or undo journal entries, AP checks, bank reconciliations, etc. The main dashboards are very friendly-user and robust. We can star the most used functions in Sage Intacct. For example, if I pay bills, print checks, bank reconciliations, download general ledgers, I can star the tabs. This allows me to spot the most used functions in the system. I also like the different entities we need and it's categorized separately. Sage Intacct have easy search bar on every page, along with different company entities. If one Sage Intacct user need to reset password, the others can assist and reset. When submitting journal entries, others can also edit or delete if needed. It's not necessary for the main user who uploaded the journal entries to edit/delete. This makes the system much for intuitive. There are options to print 1099 in accounts payable. This is really helpful for in-house companies, rather than asking third parties. We can add new accounts in the system and categorized them to expense, revenue, cash, payable accounts. It's very easy to search all the account ledgers, and multiple filters to sort date ranges, period of the year, quarterly months and account range. This definitely makes my work easier to download all reports needed during busy times like audit season, and month end closing. Transactions like funds transfers, manual payments are easily recorded and entered into the system. Sage Intacct can soft close for the month, and reopen a certain month if needed to make adjustments. Review collected by and hosted on G2.com.
column10: Sage Intacct often have new update versions, which change the interface slightly. For example, the new bank reconciliations is more difficult than the original bank rec version to view the numbers and to reconcile. The older version list all the debits/credits in one page, and the newer version list only debit/credit/all in multiple pages, which is much more difficult to match the amounts. When printing for AP checks, if we accidentally print on the current date, and realized it should be printed on a different date, we cannot void and return back to the page before. We need to print the current AP check then void and reprint with the different date. Review collected by and hosted on G2.com.
column11: Sage Intacct have made my accounting work much beneficial and finish month end closing efficiently and effectively. AP billing process are made very easy to print. There are also multiple selection for bank accounts to choose from when printing checks. We can also choose the default bank account for each company entities. When doing monthly bank reconciliations and submitted, sometimes need to undo the bank recs, there are extra steps in tracing back. The benefit of the help and support bar assisted and guided me how to undo the current bank reconciliation. There are quick and easy way to record funds transfers between two bank accounts for daily cash management, transfers in and out. It's not needed to create journal entries to record. Review collected by and hosted on G2.com.

column8: "Flexible dimensions and excellent custom reporting make Intacct a fantastic accounting suite"
column9:
I implemented Intacct for my organization after doing a lot of research and demos for 3 main reasons:
1. Custom reporting doesn't require a degree in Crystal Report writing and database setup
2. Being able to set up and work with multiple dimensions, like departments, programs, funding sources
3. Greatly increased visibility to managers and decision makers via dashboards
Other accounting software can do some of these things, but I haven't found a system that does them as easily or as well. Review collected by and hosted on G2.com.
column10: Like many accounting systems with lots of features and flexibility, Intacct is built to work with large manufacturing and distribution companies as well as small nonprofits like my group. The pricing structure may make it difficult to afford for small nonprofit companies, regardless of how well some of the features work for nonprofits. Our organization can only afford the core module, and adding just one module which includes some of the features we need would more than double the annual cost. So we've had to look for less expensive solutions outside the Intacct ecosystem. Review collected by and hosted on G2.com.
column11:
Things like budgeting/forcasting, analysis of historical data, quick answers for leadership or auditors, are all made easier and quicker with the extremely flexible AND user friendly custom reporting features.
In our small group, I'm the only accountant, so "separation of duties" is difficult to say the least. But we are able to use electronic approvals and signatures, and the Purchasing menu, so that non-accounting staff can help us stay in compliance.
Intacct allows us to make adjustments and reclass transactions easier while still maintaining an appropriate audit trail.
Managers and decision makers now have a much higher visibility in real time of how their programs are doing financially. We used to have to export data to Excel, fill out template reports, to print and give managers on paper. Review collected by and hosted on G2.com.

column9: I love that Sage Intacct is cloud-based. Our team can access the platform from anywhere. We also really like the flexibility with dimensions. column10: I am severely disappointed in the revenue aspect of the Contracts Module. Every month I have issues where I cannot post revenue and have to log a ticket. Intacct has said multiple times it is not a user error, but an issue within Intacct itself. It can take months for the issues to be resolved and when they are resolved, we are forced to open our books back months in order to have them apply the fix which is always extremely risky. It doesn't matter how urgent we list the ticket, it can still take months. It is very frustrating that the same issue happens over and over again and yet there isn't a solid fix for it. Additionally, it is frustrating that Intacct is aware the individual revenue buckets are incorrect but currently there is not a fix in the pipeline for this. It can take days to put together a deferred revenue total that is correct. It also sucks we aren't able to cancel a contract with MEA as we have many contacts who alter or cancel their contract and we need the functionality to be able to do so. Review collected by and hosted on G2.com.

column9: Sage Intacct allows us to have a single general ledger for multiple entities, new entity setup is a snap. Automated approval process makes Accounts Payable much more efficient and less time intensive. Reclass feature saves on journal entries. The attachments allow us to be mostly paperless - no more pulling invoices/reconciliations, etc. Memorized transactions save time and create checklists for month end entries. column11: The online a/p approval process has saved us lost invoices, time waiting on approvals, and streamlined the payment process. Intercompany transaction functionality has saved days of balancing at month end. Attachments make hunting for documents and pulling files a thing of the past! Reclass ability allows us to modify a paid invoice and code properly, increasing accuracy by providing historically accurate data. The memorized transaction and upload features for journal entries and invoices make large data entries simple and done in a matter of minutes! Templates are simple to use, easy to set up and upload. Customizable invoices allow us to modify invoices to reflect entity names. The system overall has allowed us to streamline, increase accuracy and saved countless hours of extra work! column9:
Contracts module makes it possible to efficiently manage complex rev rec under 606. The sync to SalesForce helps ensure a smooth end-to-end quote-to-cash process. The pre-built stat accounts for SaaS metrics are actually a game changer. It's fantastic to dimensionally track CMRR and related metrics in a custom ledger.
Stat accounts with dimensional tracking are easy to setup and administer. By using these, I am able to track all financial and non-financial KPIs within different ledgers in the system. I can then use the data to create meaningful reports for export or dashboard to share with users. By keeping everything in the system, I am able to ensure that all data is internally consistent. Additionally, if there are changes in department or class structure, by making the change at the dimension level, it will automatically cascade down to data and, ultimately, the rerports. Review collected by and hosted on G2.com.
column10: The reporting is powerful, but I would love to see an option for columns in reports to dynamically adjust based on a "start" and "end" date. Review collected by and hosted on G2.com.

column9:
Easier to navigate than other similar softwares thanks to an intuitive and user friendly UI.
Easy to upgrade with add-ons, customizations and modules.
Cloud based is great for remote acces. As we are a global company where travel is frequent, it is imperative to be able to connect from anywhere at anytime.
Easy to connect with additionnal third party software like Nexonia and Invoiced for further automations.
Easy to add users and the pricing model is fair.
Great automation opportunities, especially for companies with a lot of billing and customers.
Easy to create new entities and new sublocations (e.g. divisions) within each entity. That feature is imperative for companies that grow through acquisitions.
Love the custom report wizard feature. It helps to drive new initiatives. For example a customer with 110 locations (e.g. 110 customers in Intacct) wanted a consolidated bill. We were able to create a new summary sales report and a detailed sales report. The customers were happy.
Access granting is by section, not for the full software which allows you to manage bigger teams with people focused on processes. Review collected by and hosted on G2.com.
column10:
Some annoying bugs/challenges that are not expected out of a good accounting software. For example, AR subledger does not reconcile with GLs and we can't figure it out.
Lack of support/proactive/timely updates for international regulatory requirements.
Some functions should be more automated. FX unrealized being one of them. All the software is print out a report that basically tells you what to book but the whole entry has to be manual. Why not just create an entry proposal out of the report?
Bank feeds erase itself and work has to be redone if not fully reconciled. It would be great if bank feeds in Intacct would be working the same way as Xero does.
Deferred revenue reports are not working. It makes it hard and complicated for auditors to audit deferred revenue without a proper waterfall schedule. Also, the forecasted revenue reports based on contract modules does not work, even if we have all the data in the contract module. Review collected by and hosted on G2.com.
column11:
Billing automations for a company with 800 billings and 3000 line items. Before, everything was manually done. Now, we simply created a macro in Excels that converts the .txt file from the CRM to importable data in Intacct. Once converted, with just a few clicks its all billed, recognized (revenue) and sent to customers.
Quality reporting: Many times our upper managers inquire about details on the P&L. Intacct allows us to preserve the granularity of the transactional detail directly in the P&L' GLs. Therefore, we start searching in the P&L G&Ls and we can trace all transactions up to transactional documents.
Custom dimensions/fields: we can design new dimensions to allocate and group customers in a relevant and personnalized way to meet our managers desires. It allows us to track sales by strategic groups of customers and detect patterns that allows us to take better business decisions every month.
By connecting Nexonia to Intacct, we fully automated the employee expense report process and that is saving us dozens hours hours every month, especially at a crucial time like month-end. Review collected by and hosted on G2.com.

column8: "Disappointed by the lack of capabilities, automation and advanced functionality"
column9:
The system is fairly quick to open up and process data. We have moved from multiple Quickbooks files, and the Intacct interface is like working with software on your local machine.
Intacct does allow multi-entity functionality, though it seems a bit contrived. Review collected by and hosted on G2.com.
column10:
We have just finished our implementation after a number of months. The process was not great at all. Once the system was configured, we realized that the implementation team had left out some vital information about how the system works, and we essentially had to redesign everything and go live a month later than hoped.
We had three different implementation specialists during the process. It was started with us filling out "use case templates" with little explanation and no real relationship to the way our company does business. That process
Now that we are using Intacct for just over a month, I have realized that it lacks some basic essentials. These are truly intuitive aspects that one would expect in a system that promotes itself as one that promotes better efficiency and workflow. Nothing is automated. NOTHING
Intacct cannot import bank transactions,. Each payment made and received must be entered into the system manually and individually. Previously in Quickbooks, I could enter a full month of transactions in a matter of a couple of hours. This is a significantly more burdensome process. I will either have to hire a new accountant or pay for an add-on service to simply get back to the level of productivity we had with Quickbooks!
Our company is a healthcare company with thousands of customers. We receive batch payments from insurance companies, but there is no way in the system to receive payments from one party (insurance company) and apply the payment to another party (the insured customer). The only solution we have been given by sage is to enter a credit memo for the payer and a debit memo for each of the customers in a batch. This is triple the burden that we had in Quickbooks. Again, we probably will need to hire another accountant or two or purchase some third party application to facilitate the payments we receive.
Customers can be set up as parent-subsidiary, but there doesn't seem to be any advantage in doing so, because there is no actual relationship other than the ability to create a custom report that sorts parent and subsidiary. Even that process is so complicated that you need an IT specialist just to write the report.
The only way to import transactions is by journal entry. The problem with this is that Journal entries don't affect AR or AP. So, if you have dozens of payments received and import your bank data by journal, then your AP and AR agings and subledger won't tie to your GL anymore.
Sage seems to over-promis and under-deliver. The sales team eliminated some modules of the system in the sales process in order to make it cheaper than the competition. At this point, we have spent around $60,000 for implementation and the first year. This is a big investment for our company, and we are already having to solve significant problems because of the limitations of the system and create work-arounds.
There may be some limited solutions to these issues, but we have been warned that anything offered by Sage to provide a work-around or solution is going to be very expensive. Review collected by and hosted on G2.com.
column11: We have not been given any satisfactory answers to the dislikes mentioned above. The only benefit we have realized is the ability to generate combined (not consolidated) reports. Review collected by and hosted on G2.com.

column8: "Noble vision, but some accounting consult required"
column9:
The collaborate feature, and how we can share specific transactions and tag people (involving notifications). Some of the tech-focused aspects such as the fixed assets module and how it's set up to automatically depreciation, but also able to be downloaded as a list. Great! We have hundreds, maybe thousands of assets and that's very much how we need to reconcile - as a list like that. The fact that every screen and every view practically can be exported to CSV/excel (great for accountants). The amazing conventions each year! The roles and permissions are very fine-tuned, which is also good. Allows managers take more control over deleting items or controlling transactions without cross over segregation of duties barriers.
Overall I appreciate the tech-oriented, forward-looking spirit of Intacct. There is a lot of potential.
Also, the Intacct Community and the Design Ideas getting up-voted then implemented by engineering team is also a great aspect and I see they do implement ideas so any of the points I mentioned in the 'dislike' section will definitely be resolved in time. Review collected by and hosted on G2.com.
column10: Sometimes I feel some of the nitty-gritty aspects such as the bank recon module and the general ledger reports were designed by software developers who sort of listened to accountants on the ground and interpreted what they heard but weren't really thoroughly designed by accountants on the ground. The Accounts Payable module has the date of the check showing as the date it's selected - not the date it's printed. This is like a basic Accounting System 101 no-no. Every accounting system in the world and every bookkeeper in the world will tell you that they expect to see the date a check is printed, not the date it's selected. I mean this isn't supplemental stuff - this is a seriously basic, fundamental feature that's core to the everyday workflow of every bookkeeper in the world. Similar core design decisions in the bank recon module and GL reports that makes bookkeepers and accountants scratch their heads. Review collected by and hosted on G2.com.
column11:
The way the reports are arranged with account groups means that if you set up account groups to be ranges rather specific accounts, you can sometimes capture coding errors more easily. For instance I can immediately flag expenses which might be unusual or incorrectly coded because I set the income statement report to grab a range of accounts, and little did I know an expense went to an account we barely use and never would have predicted. Sometimes this is because an accounts payable clerk wasn't sure about a transaction, which leads to us questioning an unusual expense.
It's helpful that the General Ledger report in Intacct has account ranges as well. Review collected by and hosted on G2.com.

column10:
Navigating to help within the program is somewhat helpful. Having to log a helpdesk request and wait up to 2 weeks for a substandard reply is really awful. The lack of Support after the initial month of start-up is the most surprising part of this program, because it is so appaling. The program is much more complicated than others such as QBO, so the support should be even more accessible than it is for lesser programs.
The other issue we have grappled with is the inability of one company to pay the bills of another company without creating intercompany payables. One of our entities is a Management Company that routinely pays bills for other entities, without the expectation of repayment. We have had to create many sub locations to allow these payments, and have them aligned with the company paying the bill, while still allowing us to keep track of which entity the expense was for. Review collected by and hosted on G2.com.

column10:
In the platform reporting, it is difficult to discern how to get the information you want. I find I need to get a lot of information and then back off some of the fields because what I thought the titles meant and the information I got do not always mesh. it is frustrating to use when you are attempting to glean information in a specific format for a meeting or other reporting. There is a preview, but I would have liked to see some more guidance in the wizard, especially help in where the information will come from and which details I can get if I use that reporting format.
I also dislike that the payables ledger does not balance to the general ledger on an individual company level. If you have a multi-entity business and you have a bill for company A and that company has an intercompany relationship with Company B. You can pay the bill from company A on Company B's accounts or use the credit or whatever back and forth, however, when you balance at the end of the month, your overall (top level) AP ledger and GL ledger will balance but the individual companies will not show those outside payments for the month your balancing. Review collected by and hosted on G2.com.
column11: We were using QuickBooks for an 18 company business. Just the time savings in one chart of accounts, one vendor list and not having to sign out and into companies is a huge benefit. We've also been able to give greater detail in our reporting. We created our own paperless ap intake system utilizing the API feature Intacct offers and work with 2CP to accept online payments from our customers which automatically post to the customer's account. The online payment process is so seamless our new leases require our customers to use it to process their rent payments. Review collected by and hosted on G2.com.

column9: Our company has seen some amazing efficiency improvements with Sage Intacct - everything from cash postings, reconciliations, to using the purchasing module to approve and process invoices. We compared Sage Intacct to all the peer competitors and it is by far the best value, especially using the very inexpensive Employee licenses for items such as Dashboards. Another thing we like best is that we can make any needed changes ourselves - no need for outside consultants or programmers. Review collected by and hosted on G2.com.
column10: With Sage Intacct, if you can think of it, the application can make it happen - so our only limitations is our own time to implement new ideas and efficiencies. column11: We use Sage Intacct Dashboards to communicate financial results to our many locations in different states. Our internal communication has been greatly improved due to these Dashboards. Review collected by and hosted on G2.com.

column8: "Highly configurable and powerful, but not without its quirks"
column9:
#1 - Configurability
- Dimensions
- Configurable and visual dashboards
- Configurable, scheduled emails
- Permissions and contols
- API for pre-configured or custom integrations
- Locked into a small business discount for entirety of the relationship -- 50% discount on some add-on modules or an effective 15% off sticker
- Quickly being able to build out a set of different internal books, like a pro-forma view of what your 2 companies would have looked like financially had they always been 2 companies (not recently split off from 1).
- Great training courses (for an additional fee) and instructors Review collected by and hosted on G2.com.
column10:
#1 - Expect to spend a lot of time setting up this system -- both with your implementation partner and after. While the system is quite powerful and configurable, someone has to set it up.
- Support often takes 1 week to ping back basic responses that don't address problem; quick to kick back to you without addressing thoroughly or asking good questions to elicit more information
- Finding community suggestions that are:
-- years old
-- on expected features
-- something support referred you to recommends (as though it's a new idea and no one else has asked for it) when there's no solution
- Small business discount maxing out at 3 users -- heavy increase on subscriptions if we expand by one more business user.
- needing to ask to turn on features that are globally helpful, like audit trail or Collaborate
- Some settings are not granular enough, for example turning off an employee type user's ability to email a PO to a vendor while still providing them with related abilities for internal purposes.
- Configurable emails are limited to customers only. No customization on email to vendors.
- Using merge fields is very tedious and time consuming. If you want to build a cover letter to go with those weekly automated emails, forget it. Apparently there was once a Word plug in that assisted with this -- it's stated to be no longer supported but remains downloadable.
- The additional fee for use of APIs and a sandbox environment -- one of the selling points of the system is that it's "built to integrate with other systems" and it's primary function is as the accounting piece. So why not include these features to begin with?
- Other features: Payroll -- We don't use it because it's not offered. Selecting Intacct means you'll need to select a new payroll provider. We opted for ADP to enhance our HR offerings and use this partner's pre-integrated platform to port over weekly payroll activity. This was another big implementation we took on last year. I elected to continue using Quickbooks for payroll the next 2 quarters while we configured this piece after we had Intacct configured.
- Downloading banking activity requires a 3rd party integration, which you'll also need to separately implement with that vendor since Intacct is so highly configurable, mapping to your dimensions isn't standardized.
- There aren't a ton of pre-built reports and building reports, while powerful, is very time consuming. Review collected by and hosted on G2.com.
column11:
- Better segregation of duties through:
-- different user license levels (mail room supervisor entering digital PO request rather than turning in a paper request)
-- very precise granular permission settings on defined roles
Several features we are not using today will be used at a later time. While we implemented the accounting piece of Intacct last year, this was the first of many pieces that we are still custom developing. The purpose for selecting a more powerful accounting system was so that it could eventually serve as the warehouse of financial transactions, business rules manager of financial transaction and for building reports and dashboards for executive overview.
The real intent of moving into Intacct has yet to be realized:
-- integrating with other systems
-- greater visibility into our financial statements for better, faster decision making
I will absolutely update this review if given the opportunity once we have our custom pieces developed and integrated. Review collected by and hosted on G2.com.

column9:
First off, I love the speed of Intacct. The dashboards refresh in seconds and reports run quickly, online or offline.
Second, the user experience is excellent. I am okay with some complex screens but Intacct keeps it to the essential stuff. It's surprised me how quickly users of Quickbooks adapt to a system that's actually a lot more complex underneath.
Customizability! I can rearrange the input screens (somewhat), write my own reports and dashboards, even make SmartRules and SmartEvents to keep things on the straight and narrow. Review collected by and hosted on G2.com.
column10: I don't like how the Intacct handles company charge cards. The process for recording and paying off card charges seems unnecessarily complicated and I'm hoping they'll fix that in an upcoming release. Review collected by and hosted on G2.com.
column11:
A big one for us is Project Costing. With Sage Intacct we have timesheets and expense reports that feed right into Projects. We can bill those hours and expenses right back out again automatically. Or, for projects where we are charging a flat rate, these things go into the cost and we can instantly see whether we're profitable.
Also love custom dashboards with Performance Cards, so I can devise metrics I want to track and see them right there every time I open Intacct. Review collected by and hosted on G2.com.

column9:
When we were searching for a new accounting system to replace QuickBooks there were several requirements that were necessary have in our search and evaluation.
1) Seamless Consolidation of Muti-Entities using multiple currencies.
2) The ability to use dimensions to reduce the size of our chart of accounts.
3) Dashboards for key operating metrics and report distribution for management.
Intacct hit on all three of our requirements in a big way. The consolidation is now prepared with the push of a button whereas in the past with QuickBooks the consolidation was a very manual and time consuming process in excel that generally took about a week to prepare.
Using dimensions, we are able to tag each transaction with key attributes that were important for our end using reporting. The use of dimensions has allowed us to create multiple reports utilizing locations, regions, cost centers etc.
Dashboards have been a great way to eliminate paper reports by creating custom dashboards with key operating metrics for each manager. These dashboards are real-time and allow management to makes decisions with timely, accurate data.
4) Upload templates have also been a huge time saver for input of journal entries and accounts payable bills. Review collected by and hosted on G2.com.
column10: I really cant find anything that I dislike in the system. Review collected by and hosted on G2.com.
column11:
The benefits of Intacct have been significant. From a time saving perspective we have saved many man hours per month when we implemented Intacct. Now more time can be spent reviewing the data and being able to make timely decisions on accurate data.
The controls around the system prevent transactions from being deleted. There is always a great audit trail. I felt with QuickBooks there were no controls over data input and modifications.
The most important benefit has been being able to produce timely accurate data with the ability to deliver seamless reports and dashboards to senior management so that the business decision makers have timely and accurate data at their fingertips to make smart decisions. Review collected by and hosted on G2.com.

column10: The absent of an app to view data. One thing you need to be on the look out with Intacct, is the ability to change your configuration so easily. column8: "Reporting and dashboards leave a lot to be desired"
column9:
We really like the ease of jumping from company to company (we have 20+) and the ability to attach PDFs for our bills and journal entries. We also like the ability to automate some of the reports to run automatically.
Attaching PDF copies of our bills has allowed us to become paperless and we're saving a lot of time filing papers and then going back and searching for invoices in large filing cabinets.
Another nice thing is that we're able to make updates at the top level and then all of our various companies (entities) are updated. Example- we can add an account number and it will show in all companies. You can also create reports at the top level and create different.
We also love the ability to create bills and cut checks from multiple companies at the same time. We previously had Peachtree and would have had to open each company and enter them separately and print separate checks. Most of our bills are entity level but the few that we have at the top level saves a ton of time.
The help features in Intacct were really helpful when we first started. My team had limited training and was able to get through our first month end within a reasonable amount of time for 22 sets of financials. They used the help feature a lot at first or when new types of transactions come up. Review collected by and hosted on G2.com.
column10:
Unfortunately, this is a long list and seems to be growing......
Our implementation didn't go nearly as well as hoped. The CPA firm that we worked with struggled with getting our information transferred to Intacct and wasn't able to fully understand our business model so they didn't set us up correctly. It got frustrating for us and things weren't getting done correctly/timely so I ended up doing most of the work. In the end it saved us a lot of money but at the same time was a lot more work.
We set up all of our general ledger accounts to have a department dimension for reporting. After converting all of our accounts over and using this for over a year, we found out we couldn't run reports with the account and department number showing in the same report. Seems simple but was told it would cost tens of thousands of dollars to create this one report for us. If we would have known this from the beginning we never would have added the department dimension as part of our structure.
Another issue we've come across is that the "dashboard" is far more basic than we had expected. We were told that if the information was in the system, we could create any report with graphs etc. that we wanted. We've struggled being able to create a dashboard that actually has graphs that meets our needs. The only solution that's been given to us is to have a third party add-on for this type of service. We haven't worked with any yet due to cost and the fact that we just spent a lot of money switching to Intacct but its likely in our future because of the limitations Intacct has with its reporting/dashboards.
Review collected by and hosted on G2.com.
column11:

However, we did have a weekly operational report that was previously done in Excel that we now export directly from Intacct. This has save a lot of time and we don't have to worry about Excel formula issues.
We are currently also working on creating bill imports which should save a lot of time if we are able to get all 22 of our companies on board. Review collected by and hosted on G2.com.

column9:
Hired into a lab services company that needed a foresenic post-fraud reboot for a small-medium sized company. With the fantastic excel data upload feature In four months I was able to convert them from cash-to-accrual and populate the GL with an almost years worth of data that had to be scrubbed before upload. A great Bank recs process further helped verify the process. We do not use Receivables / Sales as we have an in-house solution. For auditability I can attach invoices, reconciliations, and documents to verify wires, account balances and other audit evidence requirements. We don't have time to file so we convert everything to pdf and upload.
I started the company on an electronic PO system which works well for what we do which is distributed purchasing. I also was able to implement departments which was a new concept for the company.
We have added the sister company which will be manufacturing.
I have learned through many system implementations that you pick a strong core and implement different best-in-breed solutions that interface, as once system can't do it all. This is a great and strong core system. Review collected by and hosted on G2.com.
column10: Small business pricing, it is expensive on a per-user license, I have discussed with them the need for a one price for x licenses not dependent on user-types. Some aspects of some fields won't work if you don't have another module, such as inventory, but you learn to work around it once you know about it. Review collected by and hosted on G2.com.
column11:
Core Accounting: Great Efficiency for a lean staff, verifiability from an audit perspective, scalability both in size and in commonly-owned entities. We have left QuickBooks!!!!! I can very easily post intercompany transactions and we will need multi-currency in the future.
I plan for a 5-10 year useful life and Intacct is anticipated to meet our needs throughout this period.
I do not do many recommendations but I would recommend this program, without a doubt. Review collected by and hosted on G2.com.

column9:
- User friendliness of the set up of the system. Each area has a set up configuration that is very easy to understand and figure out without the need for a lot of professional services. After Go Live, and we were more on our own, it's been easy to tweak the set up ourselves.
- The "help" on each field is a very nice feature!
- Standard Reports that are pre-built made it easy to get started
- Our implementations team rocked! I like the turn around time and responsiveness of the support team when I put in a ticket. Review collected by and hosted on G2.com.
column10:
- I don't like that the Top Level dashboard doesn't show you the entity that has an approval needed - I have to go through each entity to see if there is a journal or payment that needs to be approved.
- The entity should be more of a "dimension" than a separate area - should be a filter on the Top Level so that I don't have to go from page to page
- Report writing - sometimes easy, sometimes difficult - I can customize an existing standard report, but then some features of the wizard are not available - and when using the wizard, some features of the standard report are not available - needs to be more consistent
- Dashboards need to be more configurable
- Prepaid expense module needs to have a standard report that ties to the general ledger Review collected by and hosted on G2.com.
column11:
- We have gained efficiencies in processing revenue transactions, as well as better visibility to our revenue waterfall which enables us to have more accurate revenue forecasts.
- Extracting data is a "push of a button"
- Consolidating our financial statements has become easier and more accurate - we used to do these in excel. Review collected by and hosted on G2.com.

column8: "We have had Intacct since March of 2009."
column9:
There are so many reasons why I like Intacct. The ease of use for our employees is probably one of my favorites. We are a growing software company and every new employee gets a sign in to Intacct so that they can enter their time sheets and expenses. Most employees need minimal training and some have logged in and gotten started without training.
Another of my favorites is the dashboards and how easy it is to put a report on one and to make them look professional. We have dashboards for all department heads and even one that is for the typical employee. Now with the latest enhancements getting the most up to date and important info is even easier. The dashboards make me look good to my boss which is a great plus. Review collected by and hosted on G2.com.
column10:
Dislike seems little harsh, but if I could change something it would be to make Intacct more flexible. What I mean about this is that we are a small private company and some of the GAAP rules that Intacct has in place don't always apply to us and we would like to see more flexibility when it comes to being about to change or reclass entries in all modules.

column10: During the due diligence process we indicated that the global search function was of great importance to us. While I was given assurances that Intact could meet our needs that has not proven to be the case. The search function has been improved but is still not even half of what we had with Quick Books, even though the annual price to operate QB's is about 2% of what we pay for Intacct. I will give the customer support team credit for attempting to fix the issues but after 2 years I have given up and live with what I have. The sales tax module/reports are poor - the solution I was provided was to purchase an add on product provided by a third party. Review collected by and hosted on G2.com.
column11: The budget tool is much better then the one provided by our previous software provider and we have more reporting capability. The ability to sync with Sales Force is a huge benefit.
